This ease of separation gives them a great advantage over homogeneous catalysts. Thus, many attempts to immobilize catalytical- ly active species on inorganic supports have been made, see for example [1 - 7]. Acid-catalyzed reactions are the most important reactions involved in the rearrangement and conversion of hydrocarbons. Ion exchanged resin catalysts having benzenesulfo groups are known to exhibit relatively high activity and selectivity for acid-catalyzed reactions at lower reaction tem- perature [8, 9]. However, resin catalysts have the disadvantages of weak thermal stability, weak mechanical strength and swelling properties [10]. The present letter concerns the preparation of new silica catalysts modified with benzenesulfonic acid derivatives and their behavior as acid catalysts. Two types of modified silica catalysts with benzenesulfo groups were prepared: catalyst A ($Si OCH2 Q> S03H): 10 g of silica gel (Davision 952 grade) was added to a mixture of 20 g phenylmethanol and 40 g tetra- decane, and was refluxed under stirring for 5 h. The sample was then filtered and washed with benzene and acetone. The esterified sample was added to a mixture of 16 ml chlorosulfonic acid and 60 ml of chloroform, and was refluxed under stirring for 3 h [11]. The final catalyst thus prepared was filtered, washed with chloroform, and dried at 50 C. The silica thus chlorinated was phenylated by adding 350 ml 0.5 M phenyllithium solution dropwise (in a mixture of cyclo- hexane and diethyl ether) to the sample, followed by heating at 40 C under stirring for 1 h [12]. The sample was then filtered, washed with methanol and acetone, and dried at 50 C. The phenylated sample was sulfonated by the same procedure as catalyst A. Catalyst A exhibits 3030, 2960-2850, 1500-1350, 750 and 700 cm"1 bands which are attributed to the aromatic ring or methylene group, respectively [13]. Catalyst B exhibits 1420 and 700 cm"1 bands which are attributed to ^i O . For both catalysts, the intensity of the 950 cm"1 band corresponding to the surface silanol of silica decreased slightly as com- pared with that of the original silica. Thus we presume that the surface silanols were phenylated or esterified, and for catalyst B the surface phenyl group was bonded directly to the silicon atom of silica. It is reported that the S 0 stretching vibrations of the sulfo group appear in the region of 1400 - 1300 and 1200 ~ 1100 cm"1 [14]. However, it was difficult to ob- serve these bands due to overlapping with those of the skeletal vibrations of silica, as shown in Fig. 1. Fig. 1. Infrared spectra of silica gel and modified silica catalysts: (a) original silica gel, (b) ^Si-OCHi-Q-SOaH catalyst, (c) ^Si-O-SOyH catalyst. L3 Catalytic activities were measured in a pulse-type microreactor con- structed of 1/4 inch stainless steel. The catalyst were activated by heating under flowing N3 gas for 1 h at 100 C followed by 1 h at 200 C. Pulses of 1 Jiil reactant were injected into a N2 gas stream which passed over 0.01 ~ 0.1 g catalyst at 15 ml min~1. During the 2-propanol dehydration reaction, a diethyleneglycol succinate on Shimalite column at 150 C was employed, while for the cumene dealkylation reaction a bentone 34 on Chromosorb W column at 130 C was used. Conversions were taken as the average of the first to the sixth pulse values. The two catalysts prepared were tested as acid catalysts for 2-propanol dehydration and cumene dealkylation. The catalytic activities for both reactions are listed in Table 1, together with specific surface area and acidity, where chemisorption of ammonia was employed as a measure of acidity [15]. Both catalysts were active for both reactions. However, as shown in Table 1, catalyst B is more active than the catalyst A. The higher catalytic activ- ity for catalyst B may be attributed to its higher resistance to water, higher acid strength and better thermal stability as compared with catalyst A. The acidity of catalyst B is twice that of catalyst A, as shown in Table 1. The silica sample such as catalyst A esterified with alcohol shows poor resistance to water due to hydrolysis, while catalyst B, whose surface silicon atoms were bonded directly with the benzene ring, is very resistant to water [13]. Alcohol dehydration takes place very readily even on the weaker acid sites, while cumene dealkylation requires acid sites of moderate strength [16]. In view of the above facts and the catalytic data in Table 1, it is obvious that the acid strength of catalyst B is considerably greater than that of catalyst A. By thermal analysis, it was observed that catalyst A began to decompose at 430 C, and catalyst B at 530 C.
